dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To establish. A school marquee with removable plastic letters reads, "GOOD LUCK WITH FINALS!" A JANITOR opens the glass and starts removing the letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POP! A Champagne cork hits the ceiling. TEACHERS who rarely get to drink at work, jockey for position, holding out their plastic flutes. (Note: female teachers outnumber male teachers 12:1.) PRINCIPAL WALLY SNUR, 40s, balding, faces the teachers. He has a habit of blinking hard before speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's been another great year here at JAMS. Who can forget Mr. Pinkus' haunted classroom? Sandy, thank you. SANDY PINKUS, 40s, sporting a ponytail, smiles, clearly enjoying the small compliment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't afraid of no ghost. The other teachers laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or the wild success of...

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: Wally, can I just say one quick thing? Wally turns to AMY SQUIRREL, late 20s, cute and wholesome. Any trace of sexuality she might have is wiped away by her adult pigtails. She treats students and adults alike -- like students.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just wanted to remind everyone the school day's not over. So let's keep the drinking under control, hmm? That's it. Back to you, Wally. A bunch of teacher roll their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Amy, (then, back to his notes) . Or the wild success of the book drive for the women's prison sponsored by Ms. Savicki's class? A broad-shouldered teacher with spiky hair, MS. SAVICKI,

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL SNUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But now as the summer is upon us, it's time to not only say goodbye to another school year, but to also say goodbye to a member of our faculty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth, can you come up here? ELIZABETH HALSEY, mid 20s, pretty and petite, walks up to the front. She sports an enormous diamond ring and dresse slightly more cosmopolitan than the other teachers.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL SNUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You've only been with us for one short year, but know that you'll always be a part of the JAMS family. Elizabeth gives Principal Snur an appreciative smile. The Teachers lightly applaud.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL SNUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And we got you a little something. Wally hands Elizabeth an envelope. She opens it and. pulls out a gift card: BOSTON MARKET. $37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost forty dollars. Thank you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you say a couple words?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Um... I'm not really good at this type of thing so I'll make it quick. I know I've only been here a year, but there's so much I'm going to miss...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth sits at her desk, cleaning it out. She's tossin the few personal effects she has into a banker's box.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: My students, probably most of all.I'm not saying they were little angels, butthey were all there to learn and that'sthe greatest gift a student can give a teacher. Elizabeth's class is horsing around, enjoying the last days of seventh grade. A dim-looking BOY tentatively approaches her desk with his yearbook in hand. He hands it to Elizabeth, who considers what to write for a beat, then smiles as she signs it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth walks down the hall holding her box. SIXTH, SEVENTH and EIGHTH graders all race past her, running toward their summer vacation.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And I wish that I had gotten to know all of you better, but between four classes and planning a wedding, I had my hands full. From the little I do know about you, I know that our students are in good hands. Elizabeth passes Amy's classroom, where she is carefully removing inspirational posters from her walls and rolling them into cardboard tubes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three middle school BURNOUTS are smoking weed in a thicket on the outskirts of the school property.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And I can't believe it's all over. This year flew by. And even though I'll never teach again professionally, I've realized that I don't need a blackboard and classroom to set an example. Elizabeth comes up behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hand it over. The Burnouts' eyes all go wide and they freeze. One of the burnouts hands her the joint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything. The kids look at each other and then pull out a bag with a couple of joints. They hand it over to Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was a warning. Next time, I don't call the principal. I call the cops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth walks to her brand new MERCEDES. She gets in, pulls out a joint and lights it. She takes a huge TOKE, and then PEELS out of the lot. She tosses her banker's box out the window and extends her hand, giving the school THE FINGER.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Woo-hoo! A couple students look at her strangely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dim-looking kid that had Elizabeth sign his yearbook. He flips to the faculty section, and by the picture of Elizabeth is her message: "YOU ARE ILLITERATE!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (struggling to read) You are... Illit... Illit... Elizabeth's car comes barrelling toward him and nearly hits him. She accelerates into the speed bumps, almost hitting the JANITOR from the opening shot, who's changing the plastic letters to read, "HAVE A GREAT SUMMER!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slow down!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TOWNHOUSE NIGHT
dialogues.text: A Mercedes with the vanity plate "HIS" is parked in the driveway of an upscale neighborhood. Elizabeth's matching Mercedes pulls into the adjacent spot. Her license plate reads "HERS."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bachelor pad. Top of the line electronics. Lots of black leather furniture. Tacky, but expensive. Elizabeth pours two glasses of wine and takes a long sip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby Doll?

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Coming! MARK, early 30s, exits the bedroom in his underwear. He's shaved his head to avoid signs of early balding and is also a full four inches shorter than Elizabeth. Thankfully for him, he has money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! That was a quick party. Elizabeth kisses Mark on the top of his head and hands him a glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. You should have seen it. What a joke. She raises her glass for a toast. He raises his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's to me never having to work again. And I owe it all to you, Lover. Elizabeth takes a big sip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I made a reservation at Ruth's Chris, and then I booked us a suite at the Drake, and I thought we could finish the night in "anal alley." Hmm? Something drops in the bedroom. Mark, alarmed, turns towards the door. Elizabeth brushes past him into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth enters to find -- NOTHING. Mark follows her in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth looks around -- under the bed, in the closet, behind the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See? Nothing. Just then, the wooden chest at the foot of the bed SNEEZE Elizabeth opens the latch to find SHEILA, 23, dressed onl in a thong, scrunched in the fetal position. She stands, revealing LARGE FAKE BREASTS, and steps out of the chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Motherfucker!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could you do this to me?! I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are buying me the biggest pair of yellow diamond earrings they make! I'm talking serious blood diamonds. Sheila SNEEZES again. Bless you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of my house, bitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't talk to her like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me? I love her. Mark puts his arm around Sheila. Elizabeth eyes Sheila's large breasts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You love her? She's a hooker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not a hooker. I dance. Elizabeth takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Marky, you made a mistake. You're human. I'm human. And this time it was you. Maybe six months from now, you'll walk in on me. I don't know, but probably. Sheila SNEEZES again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut the fuck up. (then, to Mark, sweet) And. maybe I'm talking crazy, but I don't want to throw away our life together over something like this. We're getting married! I'm willing to fight for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not. And you know why? Because Sheila loves me -- and not just for my money. Sheila squeezes his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry if I care that my future husband can support me. We didn't all grow up with a silver spoon in our mouths. You can't even imagine what it's like going to bed hungry, night after night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?! Both your parents are CPAs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My parents worked their asses off to send me to private school. Do you know what it's like driving a Pontiac when everyone else gets a Beemer the second they menstruate? That shit stays with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's over, Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the record, there's a shitload of things that I hate about you, but I still, would've gotten married. (beat, sweet) Because I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rolls his eyes) I'm gonna need the ring back. She grabs her bag and heads for the exit. Mark follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sad little troll! I hope you and your hooker enjoy chlamydia together!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth. The ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not turning around) I'm not even listening to you anymore. She starts to open the door. He closes it. The ring!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I even want your gay-ass ring. She tries pulling it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not coming off. I'll go to the jeweler's tomorrow. Mark takes her hand and removes the ring with ease. Elizabeth steps out into the night. The door SLAMS behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A red 1994 Grand Am with a cracked windshield peels into the half-empty lot and screeches to a halt. The license plate reads "HERS."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth walks down the empty hall. It's possible a person has never looked less happy to be anywhere. FAINT SOFT ROCK plays from an open door. Something from inside the classroom catches Elizabeth's eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under her breath) You've gotta be shitting me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room has been decorated to within an inch of its life. Every surface is covered with posters like "Noted African-Americans," or "Hispanic American Hall of Fame," or "Women Who Dared." A RED DELICIOUS APPLE has been placed on each student's desk. Amy, dressed casually in cargo shorts and texas, is tryin to hang a large "INTEGRITY" poster. She looks over, sees Elizabeth staring at her, and immediately lights up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth Halsey, as I live and breathe!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy Squirrel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know we barely got a chance to get to know one another last year -- what with you planning the wedding of the century and me juggling all my extra-currics -- but I just want to say that I'm super excited to be across-the-hall-mates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I know you kinda skated by last year, doing the bare minimum thing -- you were kind of a lone wolf -- but now you're back and I just know that you are going to rededicate yourself to the task at -- Amy notices Elizabeth's bare hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your beautiful ring?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My fiance and I broke it off. I found him in bed with someone else. Oh my gosh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was another man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut the front door! (motioning for a hug) Somebody needs a hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hm. Another time then. Elizabeth takes an apple from a desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These washed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. I'd never serve a student unwashed fruit. CRUNCH. Elizabeth takes a huge bite out of the apple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought the teachers got the apples.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I think the students teach me at least as'much as I teach them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stupid. Elizabeth tosses the mostly uneaten apple into the trash and exits. It hits the rim and lands on the floor. Okey-dokey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like an asylum -- nothing on the walls. Elizabeth reads from a stack of US Weekly's and circles pictures of CELEBRITY BREASTS. LYNN, late 30s, the kind of woman who spends a lot of time on her internet dating profiles, but rarely gets emailed, pokes her head in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh sorry, am I interrupting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um -- kinda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to grab some lunch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in the middle of something, Lynn. My treat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth and Lynn sit at an outdoor table. Lynn picks at a garden salad. Elizabeth is eating a bucket of chicken and drinking a large drink. She pulls a bottle of cough syrup from her purse and dumps it into her drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have that thing going around, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you excited for tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is tomorrow Saturday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's the first day of school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, I thought I had a week to get my class together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that was last week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under her breath) Fuck my ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you hate teaching so much, why don't you just get another job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And do what? Sell perfume at the mall? Work at a day care center? (slurps her big gulp) You know, when I first got into teaching, I thought I was doing it for all the right reasons: short hours, summers off, no accountability.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love my summers. Fresh corn. Mmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From now on, my full-time job will be finding a guy who will take care of me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh god, I pray for that --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that makes a shit ton of money and doesn't ask too many questions. (licking her fingers) I spent most of my summer hanging out at the bars near where the Bulls practice. Had some fun, got some cool souvenirs that I Ebayed, but those guys aren't looking to settle down. And they all wear condoms. And then they take the condoms with them. That's how paranoid they are that a girl will try and get pregnant. Like it's so easy to get pregnant from a guy nutting into a condom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna find someone great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been thinking about it a lot. I mean, I figure I'm like an 8, 8.5. But once I get my new tits, I'll probably be a --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want to do that. You're already so pretty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know I'm hot, Lynn, but I don't stand a chance against all those Barbies dolls out there. Anna Nicole had it right, may she rest in peace. Lynn checks her watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should finish up. Wally's doing that big orientation for teachers in the auditorium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm not going to that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's mandatory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ("I'm so scared") Ooohhh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I probably won't go either. I don't know I might. I'll probably go, but just sit in the back. Maybe leave early. Maybe stay till the end. Play it by ear. Or just stay till the end. Lynn takes both their, trays and dumps them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it was alright. When you said you were taking me to lunch, I kinda thought it was going to be nicer, but this was okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay. You can get me next time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much character, not many furnishings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth is online looking at a PORN SITE. She stares at the SCREEN and compares breasts to the ones in US Weekly. She reaches for a bong and pulls a huge hit. The front door opens and her roommate, KIRK, early 30s, boarish and carrying a tattered backpack and a Big Gulp, walks quickly past Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Kirk, what do you think about me with Jessica Simpson's tits? He stares at her chest intently. She's not bothered by it Go bigger. Kirk enters his bedroom and slams the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool, yeah. She glances at the clock: 3:14 AM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under her breath) Fuck my ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth is asleep. After a beat, the ALARM goes off. She checks the clock: 5.:15. She groans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First day of school excitement. The bell RINGS, and like rats, the KIDS scurry to their various classes. Before long, the hallway is empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In one corner, CHASE, clearly at the top of the seventh grade food chain, shows off a photo spread of herself modelling in a "Western-Style" clothing catalogue. GARRETT, 12, wearing grey, stained sweatpants and a grey sweatshirt with block letters that read "GYMNASTICS," stares longingly at Chase from a few desks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The photographer was, like, sooo nice. He made me feel sooo comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might get flown to Kansas City for their fashion week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my. Chase and her friends turn to face Garrett, who's as surprised as they are that he spoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stalk much? Garrett quickly turns away. Chase rolls her eyes. An angry-looking kid, TRISTAN, wearing a MICHAEL VICK JERSEY, turns to Garrett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faggot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bless you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you say to me? Elizabeth, with large bags under her eyes, enters the class. Tristan, on a dime, heads back to his seat. The class immediately quiets down. SASHA, 12, dressed like a paralegal, walks up to Elizabeth with a large Tupperware tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm Sasha. It's a pleasure to meet you. (handing over tupperware) My mother baked these for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not looking up) Just leave them on the desk. Sasha, confused, gently puts them down and stands there. After a moment, Elizabeth looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need something?
- Sasha shakes her head and retreats to her desk at the front of the class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone here seen "Stand and Deliver?" Show of hands. (off their blank stares) No one? Edward James Olmos? Wow. Elizabeth takes a DVD from her bag. She points to two KIDS in the front of the class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and you, go grab the TV and roll it up front. (pointing to Sasha) And you, go shut off the lights. The two kids, SHAWN and SPENCER, roll the TV over. Sasha shuts off the LIGHTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're watching a movie on the first day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's awesome. You rock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree with Chase. Elizabeth pops in the DVD. "Stand and Deliver," starring Edward James Olmos as a tough-as-nails calculus teacher in an inner-city school begins. Elizabeth takes a bite of one of Sasha's cookies and immediately spits it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugh. Oatmeal raisin? She pushes the Tupperware tray into the trash next to her desk. Sasha looks on, sadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lunch is in full swing. Each clique has staked its own territory. Several TEACHERS, Elizabeth and Amy among them, are on lunch duty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GARRETT, sitting alone, writing in a journal. Tristan, the bully, tosses a bowl of cole slaw at Garrett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incoming! Direct hit. The cole slaw nails him in the shoulder. Garrett picks some of the cole slaw off his shirt and eats it. He continues writing. Amy races over to Tristan and writes him up. Elizabeth watches, bored, struggling to keep her eyes open. Amy heads over to Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody's got a case of the sleepies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see what just happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that one kid hit the other kid with the cole slaw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weren't at the orientation the other day, but we're doing something new this year. It's very exciting. We're splitting the cafeteria into quadrants. Elizabeth yawns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, anyways, in order for the quadrant system to work, it's vital that each teacher maintain order within their quadrant. Because it's really tough for me as head lunch monitor -- or another teacher -- to leave their quadrant to discipline a kid in another quadrant. I know it's a lot to take in. I'd be happy to sit with-you after school and explain all of the new guidelines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell you what. Why don't you send me a memo, and if I have any questions, I'll come to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Elizabeth. Sounds like a plan, Stan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I meant to ask you. Did I hear that you were showing a movie this morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do I know what you heard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fair enough. Listen, I don't want to tell you how to run your class, but maybe it might be fun to do some ice-breakers. Like "Telephone Charades" or "The String Game." Or start doing practice questions for the state test. It's never too soon to start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we gonna have a problem, me and you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, shishkebobs, no. If I gave you that impression, I am so sorry. Actually, I was really hoping that we could be more than across-the-hall-mates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you've heard, but I don't munch box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, of course not. I don't even know what that is. I just meant friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like getting manicures and going shopping on Sundays? Shit like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! Yes! And helping each other out. Looking out for one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's cool. Tell you what, friend, I'm gonna get going. Cover for me? Elizabeth doesn't wait for an answer, walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you can't leave. Lunch doesn't end for another... (looks at clock)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven minutes. Who's going to watch your quadrant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Empty. Elizabeth looks around and spots the "INTEGRITY" poster on the wall. She walks over and studies it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth walks down the hallway with the rolled up poster. She. passes a man, obviously lost, looking at a map. This is SCOTT, 30. Handsome in a wholesome way. Elizabeth walks by as he looks up at her helplessly. She turns on her heels. Fresh fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi there. You look a little lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Can you tell me where Room 124 is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do you one better. I'll take you there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you don't have to do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you stop? It'd be my pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks! I feel like I've been walking around in circles for the last fifteen minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott Delacorte. I'm the new sub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth Halsey, 7th Grade Language Arts. Welcome, welcome. They shake hands a beat too long. Elizabeth notices Scott's VERY EXPENSIVE WATCH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helluva watch. What's that -- a Jaeger- LeCoultre?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good eye!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. I love men's watches. It's kind of a hobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a bummer knowing my watch could feed a village for .a year, but my grandfather designed it, so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh? Your grandfather designs watches?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family business. My mom's maiden name is Jaeger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My parents had a minor meltdown when I decided to join the Peace Corps and become a teacher. But they've been cool about it. Elizabeth smiles and they start walking down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Integrity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to poster).. The poster. "Integrity." What a great message for the kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I got it. They turn a corner. Garrett wheels his backpack past them

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Ms. Halsey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey... dude... She slaps him five. Scott notices, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, I can't wait for the day that I have my own classroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... So did you and your wife just move to town?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me neither. I was engaged until I walked in on my fiance cheating on me. With his brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's horrible!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooh, 124! This is me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you, Scott Delacourte. Hopefully, we'll be seeing a lot of each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only if a teacher gets sick. Great meeting you, Elizabeth Halsey. He heads into the room. Elizabeth cocks her head, checking out his ass as the door closes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very nice meeting you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PAIR OF PERFECT FAKE BREASTS. A hand cups them from underneath. Pull back to reveal DR. VOGEL, 40s, and his receptionist, DANNI, probably in her 40s, with her shirt off. Elizabeth watches, rapt.

dialogues.speaker: DR. VOGEL
dialogues.text: As you can see, the weight is evenly distributed and there's minimal scarring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Vogel.

dialogues.speaker: DR. VOGEL
dialogues.text: (holding out his hands) "Best Hands in Chicago."

dialogues.speaker: DR. VOGEL
dialogues.text: Absolutely. Take them for a spin. Elizabeth reaches out, squeezes Danni's breasts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. And the nipples are just... I love them. I'll take two. They all laugh. Elizabeth notices Dr. Vogel'.s watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maurice Lacroix. That's a great watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how's that going?

dialogues.speaker: DR. VOGEL
dialogues.text: She's my rock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, thanks, Danni. Danni puts her bra and blouse back on and exits.

dialogues.speaker: DR. VOGEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, Elizabeth, have you given any thought to size?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking, you know, maybe a D.

dialogues.speaker: DR. VOGEL
dialogues.text: IJh huh, uh huh. I ,would say, though, with your frame, you might consider something smaller. A large B, maybe a C cup. You'd be surprised how significant those would look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm. Yeah, I think I'll go with the D's, really turn some heads.

dialogues.speaker: DR. VOGEL
dialogues.text: You know, Elizabeth, breast enhancement's not a cure-all. I just want to make sure you have realistic expectations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor, I lost my fiance to a woman with monster fake tits. So now I need monster fake tits so that I won't lose my next fiance. Those are my expectations. Is that realistic enough for you?

dialogues.speaker: DR. VOGEL
dialogues.text: Very good then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth leans over the counter and grabs a mint from a small bowl. Danni sits behind her desk wearing a headset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you'll be off your feet for about two weeks... what works for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's do December 19th. Start of winter break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 19th it is. So the total is $9300 for the surgery plus one night stay at our facility. How would you like to pay? Elizabeth laughs. Danni laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's absurd. What if I don't spend the night at your facility?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The night's included in the price. Did you not read our literature?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. A MIDDLE-AGED DOCTOR walks by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flirtatious, to doctor) Hi... (then, back to Danni) Listen, I'm a teacher, not a drug dealer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We accept all major credit cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My credit situation is complicated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, but if you can't pay, I can't schedule the appointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, there are less expensive options. Have you looked into South America?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be back. Elizabeth dramatically scoops a handful of mints from the bowl and storms out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth, her cell phone cradled to her ear, pulls a LEAN CUISINE out of a freezer STOCKED with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I just really need some money. It's, for a surgery I need. Elizabeth pokes holes in the Lean Cuisine with a knife and turns on the microwave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, as a matter of fact, it is about my breasts, dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. Happy belated birthday. So, can you wire me some money or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth walks up a driveway and looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone, whispering) So I won't beat around the bush, Grammy. She pulls the kitchen knife from her bag and SLASHES the back tire of a late-model CAMRY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone, whispering) I'm dying and I need money for surgery. Really? Nothing? Don't you get social security or something? Elizabeth goes around to another tire. Slash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth is still on the phone. CLOSE ON her computer screen. Her checking account balance: $45.66.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone, losing patience) Listen, limpdick, you owe me for breaking off the engagement. Do you know how embarrassing that was?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lover, I don't want to fight. It's just 10000 dollars and it would really mean the world to me. Lover? You there? Elizabeth hurls her phone at the wall. It smashes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking Troll! Kirk pokes his head out of his bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you call my name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I said 'fucking troll.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I thought you said Kirk. He turns and heads back in to his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you got ten grand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. Kirk closes his door. After a beat, he opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Also, I might be a little short on the rent this month. Like, a lot short.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He closes his door. The microwave BEEPS. Dinner's ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth and Lynn speak in hushed voices in the corner by a vending machine. Amy grades papers on a ratty- looking couch. She glances up at Elizabeth and Lynn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. That's a lot of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. And I hate asking a friend for money -- especially as good a friend as you. This has its desired effect on Lynn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I could sell that jewelry my grandmother gave me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That turquoise crap? Blech. No one's buying that. (then, catching herself) But it looks great on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. What about Mark?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What type of person do you think I am?! That assbag cheated on me. Did I ever tell you that he has a mole on the tip of his dick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just trying to better myself. I don't think that's asking for so much. Amy walks over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Scuse,me. Just gonna scooch in here. She drops quarters into the vending machine, but doesn't bother selecting an item. This was clearly her "in." She turns to Elizabeth and Lynn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sooo... I know it's none of my business, but I couldn't help but overhear your conversation and I just want to say, that you shouldn't change a thing. You should be happy with the way you are. That's true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh. Well, do you think mental retards should be happy with the way they are? Amy stammers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn, you teach them. What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never asked them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would never --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't all have your tits, Squirrel. So maybe you should think before you interrupt a private conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess that's what you get for trying to help... Amy pushes the coin release on the vending machine and takes back her change without getting a drink. Amy heads back to the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. Walk away. (then, noticing)- There he is! Scott enters. All of the female teachers light up. There he is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, look what the cat dragged in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish it was under better circumstances. Stu Riley's car was vandalized last night. Right in his driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gang members, probably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The public school system failed them. Elizabeth and Amy nod vigorously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An empty hallway.

dialogues.speaker: JOE CLARK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: So forget about the way it used to be. This is not a damn democracy! We are in a state of emergency and my word is law! There's only one boss around here, and that's me. The HNIC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The class is watching "Lean on Me," with Morgan Freeman a a tough-as-nails principal in an inner-city school. Amy's "Integrity" Poster now hangs above the TV.

dialogues.speaker: MS. LEVIAS, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Head Nigger In Charge. The bell RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll pick this up again tomorrow. The students shuffle out. Garrett hustles after Chase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite a film, huh? Chase gives him a weird look and then exits with her frie Sasha lingers by Elizabeth's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking up) What.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a student leader for the D.C. trip --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shocker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we're having our car wash this weekend. If you're around, maybe we could wash your car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got some Mexicans who already do it for nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's for a good cause. This year, we're trying to get some extra money so that we can go on a Duck Tour! She hands Elizabeth a flyer. Elizabeth glances at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last year's seventh grade raised $6000.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth walks past the SCHOOL SECRETARY toward the Principal's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't go in there. He's with a student. Elizabeth ignores her, adjusts her blouse, and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The office is decorated with a DOLPHIN motif. Figurines, a picture of Principal Snur kissing a dolphin. Dolphin calendars. This guy loves dolphins. Principal Snur sits next to ARKADY, a small pale kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't like to get wet, Arkady, you could try using deodorant, anti-. perspirant, maybe some cologne. I know a lot of the older boys are wearing the body spray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bodish spray. Elizabeth enters and immediately recoils from the smell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blugh! Arkady and Principal Snur both look up. He holds up his finger -- "one minute." Elizabeth notices his cheap dolphin watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why don't you think about that and I'll let your teachers know that you're working on it? Arkady nods and quickly exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, I didn't realize you were in with anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were just finishing up. Elizabeth, I actually meant to talk to you. Did I hear that you were showing movies all last week?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um... some clips, maybe. I think in a lot, of ways, movies are the new books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh. Elizabeth tries a different tact. She picks up a dolphin- shaped clock from the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this new? I love it! I think dolphins are smarter than humans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too! And if you like that, you'll love this.
Principal Snur pulls out an "Adopt-A-Dolphin" certificate.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL SNUR
dialogues.text: He lives in the Cayman Islands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a great story. Principal Snur visibly relaxes. He's sitting across from a kindred spirit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what else is new?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I was thinking that I want to get more involved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a nice surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Specifically, I thought I could supervise the car wash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy's been running it the last two years...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She just does so much. It might be nice to give her a little rest. Especially that early on a Saturday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so happy that you're dedicating yourself and becoming a real member of the JAMS family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It just feels so good to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy stands in the door where Elizabeth was just standing. Principal Snur is behind his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth?! For the seventh grade carwash? That's bonkers!
Amy immediately regrets saying "bonkers."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I didn't mean to blow my stack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just thought it was nice to see some other teachers step up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We raised over $6000 last year. That's a record. Is this really the best time to start experimenting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy, I see you taking on a.lot of responsibility, what with directing "Annie" and all your work with D.A.R.E. I'd just hate to see you get overwhelmed like you did in 2004. She stares at him -- clearly, this is a touchy subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. Well, I should skedaddle. Looks like someone needs to plan a Saturday morning bike ride. She turns on her heels and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth is asleep. Her ALARM goes off. It's 5:45 AM. She opens her eyes, sees the time, considers for a beat, then hits SNOOZE. She closes her eyes. - After a beat, the ALARM goes off again. She hits SNOOZE. Quick Cuts. Elizabeth hits the snooze button EVERY NINE MINUTES until 8:45. She stares at the clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garrett stands at the school entrance, holding a giant cardboard sign that reads "CAR WASH" as a few CARS pull i Chase, and the other popular girls, are dressed in seventh-grade sexy -- they've tied off their shirts. The BOYS run around spraying each other, but mostly spraying Garrett. Garrett laughs, mistakenly thinking that he's part of the fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm gonna get you guys! A couple of PARENT CHAPERONES stand in small clusters. Tristan, the bully, cocks his arm and aims a soapy sponge at Garrett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa. The CAMERA FOLLOWS Tristan's gaze. ELIZABETH steps out of her car. She's wearing HIGH HEELS, DAISY DUKES and a BIKINI TOP. She looks both spectacular and ridiculous. A couple of PARENTS look over at Elizabeth, in shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling to Parents) Sorry I'm late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to other PARENTS) I'm going to say something about her outfit. The MOTHERS vigorously nod in agreement. A DAD pipes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring hard at Elizabeth) Well, if it helps raise money... The other DADS vigorously nod in agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Elizabeth holds the "Carwash" sign. A LINE of CARS forms. An OLDER MAN in an immaculately clean CADILLAC, rolls down his window and hands her money. --Elizabeth washes in SLO MO, shakes out her hair as she gets WET. The BOYS and their FATHERS stare at her. --The GIRLS try to mimic Elizabeth's seductive behavior. Their MOTHERS run over and pull them away. --The Older Man in the Cadillac comes back to have his car re-washed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The carwash is wrapping up. Elizabeth counts money at a makeshift table and puts the earnings into a metal lockbox. She glances around and then shoves a large clump of cash into her DAISY DUKES.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Elizabeth looks up and sees Sasha hiding behind a TRUCK, clearly spying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. Get out of here, Dummy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you stealing our money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How dare you?! I'm here early on a Saturday for you guys. And for the record, nobody likes a tattle tale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't tattled. Yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Cause if you do, I'll deny it and flunk your ass. How will that look on your resume?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say I would say anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright then. Now beat it. I've gotta finish counting this money. Sasha walks off. Elizabeth picks up a hose and sprays her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you Monday! Elizabeth waves to SASHA'S MOTHER, who eagerly waves back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANY, across the street, watching through binoculars. She's straddling her bike and is wearing a helmet and a sheen of recently-applied suntan lotion. She takes a sip from her Camelbak, and pedals away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a fish bowl with a crude sign that reads "New Tits." Elizabeth drops in fistfuls of crumpled cash and then writes in a notebook: $1300.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy walks down the hall. She sees Principal Snur slip into the bathroom. Amy walks up to the MEN'S FACULTY BATHROOM door and waits. The BELL RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shishkebobs. She hesitates a beat and then enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally is in a stall reading a brochure for a DOLPHIN TOUR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amazing.

dialogues.speaker: AMY, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Wally? Are you in here? It's Amy Squirrel. He instinctively covers himself with the brochure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy? What are you doing? Get out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy standing inside. She scrunches her nose at the smell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This'll just take a sec. I thought you might want to know that Elizabeth Halsey showed up at the carwash in a bikini top and short-shorts. It was pretty racy stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we talk about this later?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quoting some adage) "Later we'll all die, said the gator to the fly."
Another TEACHER walks past Amy, looking confused. He hesitates and then goes into an adjoining stall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Josh Gershman's dad called and said that the carwash was a huge success. And Lauren Rissman's dad called and said the kids had a great time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to speak out of school, but I happened to be pedalling by and saw her get.pretty chummy with the money. ,And remember, we barely know anything about her. She was a real lone wolf last year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you accusing Elizabeth of embezzling from the seventh grade car wash?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something about this doesn't pass the smell test, Wally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they raised over $7000, so whatever she did worked. And next time you accuse a fellow teacher of stealing, you better be damn sure. We're done here. Amy takes a deep breath. Her face is BEET RED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the pep talk. Have a super day, you two. Amy exits. Immediately, there is an IMMENSE ERUPTION from the other stall, followed by a sigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ... I thought she was never going to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sandy, the math teacher with the ponytail, sits at the table grading papers. Another TEACHER dozes in the corner

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (entering, very friendly) Hey! Are those new Doc Marten's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sandy looks behind him at the dozing teacher. "Is she talking to me?" Guilty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's Period 5?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great, thanks for asking. We got a new bassist and we finally got a regular gig, which is nice because it's earned. It's time to show the world that a bunch of teachers can really rock out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awesome!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, would you mind grabbing me my yogurt from the fridge? Sure thing. Sandy goes to the fridge. Elizabeth pulls visine from her bag, and as his head goes into the fridge, she squirts the entire container into his coffee mug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should come to one of our shows. He hands her the yogurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I can't. Elizabeth exits. Sandy sadly takes a sip of his coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't even tell you the dates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth's class is seated. They're staring at her, waiting for her to begin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we starting "School Ties" today? Elizabeth holds up her finger while she finishes reading NATIONAL GEOGRAPHIC.
The camera ANGLES to show that she is studying a picture of a topless AFRICAN TRIBESWOMAN with large breasts. After a beat, Elizabeth looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, today, we're starting "School Ties." Classic. (then, pointing to a Student) You, shut off the lights. Elizabeth goes to the DVD player. There's a knock at the door and the SCHOOL SECRETARY walks in holding a box. She hands it to a confused Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here it is. Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here what is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the pre-test for the state standardized test. It was in the memo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. In the memo. The Secretary leaves. Elizabeth stares at the box. Tristan and.a couple kids start making farting noises with their hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Zip it. Zip your shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, look, we all know these tests are gay -- Elizabeth turns to a student who COULD BE GAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Elizabeth passes the box to the front of the class, where the kids dutifully take Scan-trons and test booklets.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (then, reading) According to this memo, I'm supposed to give you forty-five minutes per section. Blah blah blah. Clear your desks, pencils out and -- begin! Twenty-five pencils hit paper in unison.
Elizabeth takes the TV and swivels it to face her desk. She turns on the movie, turns down the volume (just a little bit) and reclines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chase and another popular girl strut across the cafeteria, arm in arm. A THIRD POPULAR GIRL, saving a table, waves them over. Chase and her friend walk right past the girl like she doesn't exist and take a seat with a bunch of other girls

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little bitches.

dialogues.speaker: TURN TO REVEAL
dialogues.text: Elizabeth and Lynn on lunch duty. The girl at the table starts BAWLING. Amy, also on duty, races over to console her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a phony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major phony. But she also cares a lot, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's going on with your boobs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. Shit is going on with my boobs. I'm never gonna get married. I'm gonna die broke. I should just blow my brains out. (then, lighting up) There he is! Scott walks down the ramp and HIGH-FIVES a bunch of kids. He gives them a big wave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love how his eyes sparkle when he smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to sit on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're really making a habit out of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha, yeah. Actually, Sandy Pinkus in the Math department, I guess he got that stomach bug that's been going around and I got the call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard he pooped himself in first period. A kid had to walk him to the nurse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn, would you mind grabbing me a milk? Elizabeth gives her a "can you get out of here?" look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott, do you want anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm good, thanks for asking. Lynn walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Scott -- Lynn comes back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, what kind of milk do you want? Skim? Whole? 2%? Chocolate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Surprise me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll get you skim. No, no, 2%. Lynn walks off again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's funny. Elizabeth notices Amy looking at her as she continues to console the girl. Elizabeth turns back to Scott.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Scott, I was thinking, I would love to hear about your experiences in the Peace Corps. I love Haiti. Maybe we could go grab a drink some night. Maybe tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it Back-to-School Night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (news to her) Yeah, Silly, I meant after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool! Let's get a group together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, definitely! Or just the two of us. Scott looks around, then lowers his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Um, listen, I'm really flattered. You're one of the nicest people I've met here. But... I'm actually seeing someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we've been keeping it quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because she's ugly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. She's beautiful. She's great. She really cares about the kids. It's just... when you're dating a co-worker...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Squirrel? Elizabeth whips around to see Amy, who's now sharing a frozen yogurt with the formerly bawling girl. Amy looks up, smiles and gives a thumbs up to Elizabeth and Scott, signalling that everything's okay with the girl. Elizabet NOTICES Amy's LARGE BREASTS straining against her blouse. She quietly seethes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyways, thanks again for asking me out. I'm honored. And I'll take a raincheck on that group date. See ya! Scott crosses through the cafeteria. Lynn returns with a four cartons of milk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you go. I got you one of each.
Lynn hands them to Elizabeth, who takes them, drops them in the trash and storms off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At night, under the stars, the SCHOOL looks peaceful, ser

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth is up front. She's staring,at the PARENTS. They stare right back at her. It's awkwardly silent for a beat too long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, my name's Elizabeth Halsey. Soooooo... Any questions? Sasha's Mother eagerly raises her hand. Elizabeth points to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm Sasha's mother. We waved to each other at the carwash. I'm a little concerned with the importance you're placing on movies. What about the state test? Elizabeth points to her sign on the wall -- "Don't Question My Authority."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's exactly what I say to my students. Listen, I'm a good teacher. And the school hired me because I'm good at what I do. (as the parents take this in) And the reason your son loves my class is because I inspire him. Movies are one tool that I use. I also use other multimedia techniques, which I'm not going to get into right now. Look, I could take you day by day through my entire syllabus, but that's not how I do things. I'm not one of these stuffy teachers who's totally by the book. I talk to the kids like they're little adults. It's about mutual respect. So that's my spiel, as the Jews say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help yourselves to some delicious snacks and drinks in the back. Class dismissed. They head to the back of the class. ANGLE ON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A "refreshments" table. A lonely package of OREOS rests against a PITCHER OF TAP WATER. Elizabeth tries to sneak out the door, but is stopped by a sharply dressed PARENT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Ms. Halsey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Chris' dad. From Elizabeth's reaction, she clearly has no idea who Chris is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris... Great kid -- and precocious. You must be so proud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, what a relief. I just wish his grades would reflect it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I know Chris, he'll get there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I know you have a full plate, but if you could keep an eye on Chris, my wife and I would really appreciate it. Chris' dad shakes her hand. Elizabeth opens her hand, sees a tightly folded HUNDRED DOLLAR bill. She looks back up at Chris' dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For supplies. Or whatever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth stands with another set of parents. They're eating Oreos and sipping water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're Chase's parents? Great kid -- and precocious. You must be so proud. The parents beam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A student like that would benefit so much from some extra attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think we should hire a tutor? (then, to Chase's Dad) I told you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be happy to do it myself. It's just hard in a class of twenty-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, to be a teacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just so hard, on my salary, having to pay for my supplies, my fiance cheated on me with his twin sister... and, unlike a lot of these other teachers, all I truly care about is helping your child learn. And as their personal tutor, I guarantee a full grade higher -- or your money back. Chase's mom takes out her check book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make it out to "cash."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parents are leaving the class, ad-libbing "thank.you's." Another SET OF PARENTS surreptitiously hand Elizabeth some cash. A Bohemian mother, MELODY, wearing a beret, lingers behin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Ms. Halsey. I just wanted to introduce myself. I'm Melody. Garrett's mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you... Garrett's a great kid -- and precocious. You must be so proud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you're referring to his poetry. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be so proud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am. So so so so so proud. So proud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A kid like that, if I could just give some more one on one time, he would just blossom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so happy to hear you say that. would really benefit from that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, in a class of twenty- five...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugh. Class sizes are ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with the amount they pay teachers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank god you love what you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess what I'm getting at is, maybe you could help out by giving me a little -- you know -- somethin somethin. Elizabeth offers her hand, palm up. Melody stares back at her blankly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just, it's really tough to teach the way that I want to teach when there's so little money. I mean, look at this place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I'm going to do for you? Melody opens her pocketbook. Elizabeth smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am going to start a letter-writing campaign to the school board, to my congressman, to the mayor -- and keep writing until you get what you deserve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens her date book and writes herself a note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm writing myself a reminder! Melody pulls Elizabeth into a warm hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are a saint. Melody exits. Elizabeth is left in the classroom by herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So long, Crazy. As Elizabeth pulls out the CASH she just made, we hear the opening beats of COOLIO'S "GANGSTER'S PARADISE."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SONG continues. Elizabeth pokes her head in. The office is empty. She walks in, grabs the "Lost and Found" box and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SONG continues. Elizabeth stands across from a HIPPIE-LOOKING GIRL. The pile of "Lost and Found" clothes are laid out on the counter. The Hippie Girl hands Elizabeth some cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SONG continues as Elizabeth throws more money in her "New Tits" jar and enters a new amount into her notebook. The new balance: $1473.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Gangster's Paradise" CONTINUES and we see that the class is now watching "Dangerous Minds" with Michelle Pfeiffer as a tough-as-nails teacher in an inner-city school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SONG continues as Amy, in her empty classroom, stands against the adjoining wall, her ear pressed to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SONG continues. The class is still watching "Dangerous Minds." There's some NOISE in the hall. Elizabeth PAUSES the movie, STOPPING the song. She leans into the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough with the commotion! The hallway goes silent. She comes back in and UNPAUSES the movie. The SONG comes back on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SONG continues as the hallway fills with excited kids, who race down the hall and talk animatedly with friends. Elizabeth pushes through the center.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SONG continues. Elizabeth sits in her car. She lights a joint with the cigarette lighter and deeply inhales. KNOCK KNOCK! The SONG abruptly ENDS. Elizabeth jumps. She turns to her window, sees Sasha, bundled in her winter coat, waving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through the window) What do you want? Sasha motions for her to roll down the window. Elizabeth doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that marijuana?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is. But it's medicinal. Doctor gave it to me. Not that it's any of your business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, okay. Feel better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mom and I made you holiday cookies. Here. Sasha pulls out a tupperware container.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (peering through window) Are those oatmeal raisin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sugar. Elizabeth considers, then manually rolls down the window a crack. She grabs the container and quickly closes her window. Elizabeth starts eating a cookie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have anything to drink? Sasha shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Word to the wise: stop dressing like you're running for congress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to run for congress. I want to be president.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See? That's what I'm talking about. Keep saying stuff like that, you're gonna get punched. You really want to be President or is that what your parents tell to be? Sasha shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to decide right now. Who knows? Maybe you wake up one day and decide that you love giving massages and you want to be a masseuse. Salary plus tips. Think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I think about it, will I get extra credit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes her head) Hopeless. Watch your feet.
Elizabeth reverses. Sasha jumps away from the car. Elizabeth peels out, passing the school marquee that reads, "Happy Holidays, Jammers! See you in '09!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth rolls over. It's 3:40 PM. She yawns and gets out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: QUICK CUTS. Elizabeth opens her refrigerator. Nothing except ketchup packets, mustard packets and soy sauce packets. She reaches for her bong and tries lighting it. Once. Twice. She shakes the lighter. No luck. She carries the bong to the stove, turns on the stove, and tries lighting it from there. No luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth walks up to the door. It's locked. She shakes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously? She sees a HOMELESS GUY leaning against the storefront.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why's the store closed? The Homeless Guy looks at her strangely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously? Elizabeth looks around. The streets are empty. Not a person in sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever. (then, stops) Hey, you got a lighter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't smoke. It's bad for you. Elizabeth walks back to her car, empty-handed. A MINI- VAN passes. Stops. Reverses.. The window rolls down. It's Garrett and his Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ms. Halsey! Hey, it's me, Garrett!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas, Ms. Halsey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Having a nice Christmas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing the rest of the day? Going to see your family?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm probably going to meet up with some people. We're having a big potluck, so... Elizabeth-shuffles her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ms. Halsey. (then, extremely maternal) Elizabeth. Would you like to have Christmas with us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cozy and unpretentious. Filled with crafts. Elizabeth sit next to Melody and across from Garrett, who's wearing his "Gymnastics" sweatshirt, and his TWO AUNTS, both divorced Elizabeth tears through a plate of Christmas cuisine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a real treat for Garrett. He doesn't have a lot of friends come by the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I find that hard to believe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I hate to eat and run, but I've gotta head over to the shelter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought we could play board games!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shelter. That is so inspiring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I love helping bums.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, but you have to wait for dessert. We have a real treat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it's cheesecake, I'll stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's even better than cheesecake!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garrett, why don't you run and get some of your new poetry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feigning. embarrassment) Oh god, no one wants to hear it. Oh god, I'm so embarrassed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be shy, Marbles. Garrett runs out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're not really serving dessert, I'm gonna have to get going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One poem? If you like it, maybe you can read it to your homeless friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garrett stands in front of Elizabeth and his family. He opens his journal, clears his throat, and begins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is called "The Chase," by Garrett Tiara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: XOXO /My love for you is XOXO/ Her hair is long and straight / Isn't it great? / About her smile / That I would walk a mile for / About her personality / That makes me see the best in me / And at night when we sleep / Our souls locked in deep / So that when we sleep / We can stop pretending / And embrace our beautiful ending. Melody applauds. The Aunts join in. Elizabeth claps, then gets up to go. Garrett shakes them all off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits back down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll dance our dance / We'll revel in romance perchance / One glance / One dance / Because together we can achieve... (really reaching for it) Ba-lance... Thank you. He closes his journal. Everyone applauds. Melody looks to Elizabeth for a reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Junior likes to rhyme.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patty, Nancy, why don't you give me a hand with dessert -- give them a chance to talk about the poem. The women exit, leaving Garrett and Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So your poem's about that girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chase, yeah. You got the subtext.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I give you some advice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number one, stop writing poetry. Two: stop reading it. And three: don't set your sights so high. I mean, she's really hot. If I were you, I'd try for that chubby girl that sits up front -- the one with the teeth? Elizabeth puts her hands to show teeth going off in different directions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I like Chase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not gonna happen. Look, I was that hot girl. Hotter, even. And I never would have gone out with a kid like you. And I'm not saying that to be mean. I'm saying it to be helpful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you know? You don't-even know our names.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what I know: a kid who wears the same "Gymnastics" sweatshirt three days a week isn't getting laid until he's 26. That's what I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This sweatshirt was my dad's. It's all he left when he left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there's a reason he didn't pack it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet, steely) Fuck you. Elizabeth pats Garrett on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck being a loser. Thank your mom for dinner. Elizabeth heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy New Year. Are you spending that alone, too, or do you want my mom to invite you over? She gives him the finger over her shoulder and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The students, many tanned, many with braids in their hair from their winter vacations, silently stare at Elizabeth. She looks haggard. She pulls out a bottle of cough syrup and takes a long swig. The kids look at each other, like "what is she doing?" Elizabeth lets out a lame, fake cough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth is-checking her makeup in the mirror. Lynn enters. Her blouse has a healthy serving of vomit on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, welcome back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that, vomit? Lynn grabs some towels and blots at the stain..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and a little blood. The kids had too much sugar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyways, a bunch of us are going out tonight to see Period 5 play. Do you want to come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugh. No. Elizabeth heads out. Lynn, still blotting, follows her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth and Lynn bump into Scott.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, guys. Are you coming to 'In Cahoots' tonight? My band's doing a few songs. Could be fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, yes! That sounds like a party. (then, to Lynn) Lynn, do you want to come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll all grab a drink!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. I need to get drunk. I mean, not drunk drunk. But a strong buzz. Still be able to drive home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (high fives her) Now we're cooking with grease!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. IN CAHOOTS BAR & GRILL - NIGHT We hear the familiar riff of Shawn Mullin's "Lullaby."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. IN CAHOOTS BAR & GRILL - NIGHT - CONTINUOUS Scott, Sandy (with his hair down), a BALDING BASS PLAYER with a yarmulke and a HEAVY-SET DRUMMER, are playing their hearts out. This is PERIOD 5.
Amy, and a couple other teachers are front and_center, grooving to the music. Amy sways with her eyes closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's gonna be alright / rockabye... Scott joins in, harmonizing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rockabye, rockabye...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye, bye... Bye, bye...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth and Lynn at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't they terrific? Elizabeth eye-fucks Scott. She catches his eye and he quickly smiles before nervously turning his attention to Amy. Elizabeth watches Amy dance in SLO M0, her BREASTS bouncing up and down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring at Amy's breasts) They're perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should hear some of their originals. She turns to the bartender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two more. (then, to Lynn) You want anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks... You know, I was thinking that if you still need that money, you should.try and go for the bonus. Can't hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What bonus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the state test. (off Elizabeth's look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whichever teacher has the highest scoring class gets a bonus. We talk about it all the time in the faculty meetings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: $5700. Could be good, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's dance! Lynn runs out onto the dance floor and joins Amy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man it's a hot one / like seven inches from the midday sun... Amy kicks her shoes off, and starts dancing. Lynn follows suit. Elizabeth throws back her drink and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is breaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy listens to NPR as she pulls into the empty parking lot. Suddenly, she SLAMS on her brakes. ELIZABETH'S CAR is already there. Amy puts her car in park and gets out. She walks over to Elizabeth's car and feels the hood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clicking of Amy's shoes ECHO through the empty hallwa She stops, takes off her shoes. She pitter-patters down the hall to Elizabeth's classroom and PEERS in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth is at the chalkboard, intently writing questions. She senses something in her periphery and looks over at her window. Nothing. Elizabeth goes back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth waits in the doorway impatiently as the kids filter in. Garrett brings up the rear, rolling his backpack into class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go, Sylvia Plath. Garrett rolls his backpack over Elizabeth's shoe.. Elizabeth winces and glares at Garrett. The rest of the class enters, stops, noticing WORK PACKETS on each of their desks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the TV?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone, take your seats. Shawn turns to Spencer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think's going on? Spencer shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, come on. We have a lot to cover so sit down. The class, still confused, quickly take their seats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright then. Now. Open your To'Kill A Mockingbird to page one. The kids slowly take out their books. We HEAR the distinct sound of twenty-five book spines cracking as they're opened for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking her notes) Good. Now, who can tell me why Jem cries when the hole in the tree is filled with cement? Anyone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because she's a cry baby. The kids chuckle. Chase looks back at Garrett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
